Sentences_from: Na lewo, wśród gęstych chmur, po nad drzewami sterczały wieżyce Baskerville-Hall.
Sentences_to: In the distant hollow on the left, half hidden by the mist, the two thin towers of Baskerville Hall rose above the trees.
Translated_sentences: To the left, among the dense clouds, the Baskerville-Hall turrets perched over the trees.

Sentences_from: List doszedł rąk baroneta i był pierwsza zapowiedzią niebezpieczeństwa.
Sentences_to: With characteristic promptness and audacity he set about this at once, and we cannot doubt that the boots or chamber-maid of the hotel was well bribed to help him in his design.
Translated_sentences: The letter came to the hands of the baronet and was the first foreshadowing of danger.

Sentences_from: -- Doktor Mortimer mieszkał już tam zapewne?
Sentences_to: "But Dr. Mortimer was no doubt already stopping there?"
Translated_sentences: Dr. Mortimer lived there, probably?

Sentences_from: Posłaliśmy po Niemca, ale twierdził, że o niczem nie wie i nie umiał wyjaśnić tego dziwnego zdarzenia.
Sentences_to: "In that case the waiter must have placed it there while we were lunching."
Translated_sentences: We sent for a German man, but he claimed he knew nothing and could not explain this strange occurrence.

Sentences_from: -- Czy pani zapamiętała daty swoich listów?
Sentences_to: "Have you the dates of those letters?"
Translated_sentences: - Did you remember the dates of your letters?

Sentences_from: Choć jeszcze młody wiekiem, był już przygarbiony; na jego twarzy malowała się dobra wola względem ludzi.
Sentences_to: Though young, his long back was already bowed, and he walked with a forward thrust of his head and a general air of peering benevolence.
Translated_sentences: Though still young in age, he was already slouched; good will to people was painted on his face.

Sentences_from: Po za nim stała kobieta; pomagała mu wyjmować kuferki.
Sentences_to: She came out and helped the man to hand down our bags.
Translated_sentences: A woman stood behind him; she helped him take out the pint.

Sentences_from: Był tak wystraszony, że świeca podskakiwała mu w ręku. -- Przyszedłem zobaczyć, czy okno zamknięte...
Sentences_to: His agitation was so great that he could hardly speak, and the shadows sprang up and down from the shaking of his candle.
Translated_sentences: He was so scared that the candle was jumping up in his hand. — I came to see if the window closed...

Sentences_from: Moja żona i ja będziemy starali się dogadzać jaśnie panu, dopóki nie znajdzie nowej służby.
Sentences_to: My wife and I will be happy, Sir Henry, to stay with you until you have made your fresh arrangements, but you will understand that under the new conditions this house will require a considerable staff."
Translated_sentences: My wife and I will try to get along clearly with you until he finds a new service.

Sentences_from: Zostałem z nim przez cały wieczór i wtedy, tłómacząc swe wzburzenie, opowiedział mi całą tę historyę.
Sentences_to: I stayed with him all the evening, and it was on that occasion, to explain the emotion which he had shown, that he confided to my keeping that narrative which I read to you when first I came.
Translated_sentences: I stayed with him all evening, and then, in his excitement, he told me the whole story.

Sentences_from: Ale teraz, gdy jaśnie pan okazał nam tyle dobroci, uważam sobie za obowiązek wyznać to jaśnie panu.
Sentences_to: But now you have been kind to us, and I feel as if it would be treating you unfairly not to tell you all that I know about the matter."
Translated_sentences: But now that you have clearly shown us so much kindness, I consider it a duty to confess this clearly to you.

Sentences_from: Wstał i wszedł do jaskini. -- Ha! widzę, że Cartwright przyniósł mi prowianty...
Sentences_to: He rose and peeped into the hut. "Ha, I see that Cartwright has brought up some supplies.
Translated_sentences: He got up and went into the cave. — Ha! I see Cartwright brought me the provals...

Sentences_from: -- Kogo ja widzę! -- rzekł. -- Jeśli mnie oczy nie mylą, doktor Watson. Nie spodziewałem się spotkać pana tutaj...
Sentences_to: A figure was approaching us over the moor, and I saw the dull red glow of a cigar.
Translated_sentences: - Who do I see! “He said. “If my eyes don't mistake, Dr. Watson. I didn't expect to meet you here...

Sentences_from: Zbliżywszy się, spostrzegłem dwa kamienie, stojące prostopadle; jeden leżał na nich poziomo.
Sentences_to: But there were ample signs that I had not come upon a false scent. This was certainly where the man lived.
Translated_sentences: Having approached, I saw two stones, standing perpendicular; one lay horizontally on them.

Sentences_from: -- Jego żona! -- szeptała. -- Jego żona!
Sentences_to: "His wife!" she said again. "His wife!
Translated_sentences: - His wife! - She whispered. — His wife!

Sentences_from: -- Nasza sprawa zaczyna się zaokrąglać -- mówił Holmes, gdy w parę minut potem staliśmy na dworcu, oczekując londyńskiego pociągu. -- Jest to najdziwniejsza zbrodnia, jaka się zdarzyła w naszem stuleciu.
Sentences_to: "Our case becomes rounded off, and difficulty after difficulty thins away in front of us," said Holmes as we stood waiting for the arrival of the express from town. "I shall soon be in the position of being able to put into a single connected narrative one of the most singular and sensational crimes of modern times.
Translated_sentences: “Our case is starting to round,” Holmes said, as we stood at the train station a few minutes afterwards, expecting a London train. “This is the strangest crime that has happened in our century.

Sentences_from: Jednego tylko obawiam się, a mianowicie, żeby on nie wykonał swego zamiaru, zanim będziemy gotowi do walki.
Sentences_to: There is but one danger which can threaten us. It is that he should strike before we are ready to do so.
Translated_sentences: One thing I am afraid, namely, is that he will not carry out his intention before we are ready to fight.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli będę zmuszony wezwać pomocy policyi, wtedy dopiero przekonasz się pani, jak dalece jesteś skompromitowaną.
Sentences_to: If I have to call in the aid of the police you will find how seriously you are compromised.
Translated_sentences: If I'm forced to call police help, then you'll only find out how far you're compromised.

Sentences_from: Zapewne mógł był wyjść na spacer, ale nie w taką noc, ciemną, wilgotną.
Sentences_to: We can understand his taking an evening stroll, but the ground was damp and the night inclement.
Translated_sentences: He probably could have gone out for a walk, but not on a night like this, dark, damp.

Sentences_from: -- Przypuszczam jednak, że pragniesz pan zasięgnąć mojej rady w sprawie aktualniejszej i bardziej realnej -- rzekł Holmes.
Sentences_to: "But I understand that it is something more modern and practical upon which you wish to consult me?"
Translated_sentences: “However, I suppose you wish to seek my advice on a more current and more real issue,” Holmes said.

Sentences_from: Podczas gdym ja śledził Stapletona, on śledził ciebie, tak, że wiedziałem o każdym twoim kroku.
Sentences_to: When I was watching Stapleton, Cartwright was frequently watching you, so that I was able to keep my hand upon all the strings.
Translated_sentences: While I was following Stapleton, he was following you, so that I knew about your every step.

Sentences_from: Stanęliśmy opodal i czekaliśmy półtory godziny. Potem ci gentlemanowie przeszli mimo nas, mój pan kazał mi jechać powoli przez Baker-Street, a potem przez Regent Street, do połowy.
Sentences_to: Then my gentleman threw up the trap, and he cried that I should drive right away to Waterloo Station as hard as I could go. I whipped up the mare and we were there under the ten minutes.
Translated_sentences: We stood around and waited for hours and hours and hours. Then these gentlemen passed in spite of us, my master told me to drive slowly through Baker-Street and then through Regent Street, halfway through.

Sentences_from: Czasami zastanawiam się, czy jej nie trapią wyrzuty sumienia, a chwilami posądzam Barrymora, iż jest tyranem.
Sentences_to: Sometimes I wonder if she has a guilty memory which haunts her, and sometimes I suspect Barrymore of being a domestic tyrant.
Translated_sentences: Sometimes I wonder if she's out of remorse, and at times I think Barrymor that he's a bully.

Sentences_from: Kochany Holmes! Pozostawiłem cię wprawdzie długo bez wiadomości, za to dziś pragnę cię odszkodować.
Sentences_to: MY DEAR HOLMES,--If I was compelled to leave you without much news during the early days of my mission you must acknowledge that I am making up for lost time, and that events are now crowding thick and fast upon us.
Translated_sentences: Dear Holmes! I have left you a long time without a message, for that today I want to compensate you.

Sentences_from: -- Dlaczego pan nie chce zrozumieć, że ta przestroga ma pańskie dobro na względzie?
Sentences_to: "Man, man!" she cried. "Can you not tell when a warning is for your own good?
Translated_sentences: Why don't you want to understand that this cautionary tale has your good for your sake?

Sentences_from: Jednak szkoda, że nie zdołaliśmy go sami schwytać.
Sentences_to: He had not seen this lonely man upon the tor and could not feel the thrill which his strange presence and his commanding attitude had given to me.
Translated_sentences: However, it's a shame that we couldn't capture him ourselves.

Sentences_from: Łatwiej mu było umknąć na Regent-Street, niż na tej otwartej równinie.
Sentences_to: And I've closed the wood where the Fernworthy folk used to picnic.
Translated_sentences: It was easier for him to elude Regent-Street than in this open plain.

Sentences_from: W świetle promieni słonecznych, ślizgających się po starych zbrojach, sala jadalna wydała nam się weselszą, gdyśmy zasiedli do śniadania.
Sentences_to: As Sir Henry and I sat at breakfast the sunlight flooded in through the high mullioned windows, throwing watery patches of colour from the coats of arms which covered them. The dark panelling glowed like bronze in the golden rays, and it was hard to realize that this was indeed the chamber which had struck such a gloom into our souls upon the evening before.
Translated_sentences: In the light of the sun's rays, slithering over old armour, the dining room appeared to be a merrier one for breakfast.

Sentences_from: Usta jej poruszyły się bezdźwięcznie, wyszeptała „nie” tak cicho, że domyśliłem się raczej, niż usłyszałem to słowo.
Sentences_to: Her dry lips could not speak the "No" which I saw rather than heard.
Translated_sentences: Her mouth moved voicelessly, she whispered “no” so quietly that I guessed rather than heard that word.

Sentences_from: -- Wielu już przypłaciło życiem taką chętkę.
Sentences_to: "You would naturally think so and the thought has cost several their lives before now.
Translated_sentences: - Many have already paid their lives to such a willingness.

Sentences_from: Na płaskim, wygrążonym kamieniu, który zapewne służył przedhistorycznemu człowiekowi za łoże, była kołdra, zawinięta w pled, na ziemi pozostał jeszcze popiół od zagaszonego ogniska, obok były rondelki i blaszana konewka z wodą, w drugim rogu dostrzegłem butelkę z _ginem_.
Sentences_to: Beside it lay some cooking utensils and a bucket half-full of water. A litter of empty tins showed that the place had been occupied for some time, and I saw, as my eyes became accustomed to the checkered light, a pannikin and a half-full bottle of spirits standing in the corner.
Translated_sentences: On a flat, winded stone, which arguably served the prehistoric man for the bed, was a quilt, wrapped in plaid, on the ground there was still ash left from the covered bonfire, next to there were saucepans and a tin watering can of water, in the other corner I spotted a bottle with _ginem_.

Sentences_from: Jest doktor Mortimer, ale ten wydaje mi się zupełnie uczciwym; jest jego żona, o której nic nie wiemy.
Sentences_to: There is our friend Dr. Mortimer, whom I believe to be entirely honest, and there is his wife, of whom we know nothing.
Translated_sentences: There's Dr. Mortimer, but this one seems perfectly fair to me; there's his wife we know nothing about.

Sentences_from: „W ciągu ostatnich paru miesięcy spostrzegłem, że system nerwowy sir Karola był nadwerężony.
Sentences_to: "Within the last few months it became increasingly plain to me that Sir Charles's nervous system was strained to the breaking point.
Translated_sentences: “In the last few months I've seen that Sir Charles's nervous system has been overstressed.

Sentences_from: I tak, naprzykład, twierdzisz, że laska jest darem jakiegoś prowincyonalnego klubu myśliwskiego. Ja przypuszczam, że ofiarowali ją lekarzowi pensyonarze szpitala Charing Cross (C. C. H.).
Sentences_to: I would suggest, for example, that a presentation to a doctor is more likely to come from a hospital than from a hunt, and that when the initials 'C.C.' are placed before that hospital the words 'Charing Cross' very naturally suggest themselves."
Translated_sentences: And yes, for example, you claim that the chick is the gift of some provincial hunting club. I suppose they donated it to the doctor pensyonary of Charing Cross Hospital (C. C. H.).

Sentences_from: -- Jakim sposobem dowiedziałeś się, że ta kobieta jest jego żoną? -- spytałem.
Sentences_to: "But are you sure of this, Holmes? How do you know that the woman is his wife?"
Translated_sentences: - What way did you find out that this woman is his wife? - I asked.

Sentences_from: Dorożkarz spojrzał na niego ze zdziwieniem. -- Cóż ja panu mam mówić, kiedy pan sam wie wszystko -- odparł. -- Ten pan powiedział mi, że należy do policyi, że jest detektywem, i kazał milczeć.
Sentences_to: The man looked surprised and a little embarrassed. "Why, there's no good my telling you things, for you seem to know as much as I do already," said he. "The truth is that the gentleman told me that he was a detective and that I was to say nothing about him to anyone."
Translated_sentences: The dormant looked at him in astonishment. “Well I should tell you, when you know everything,” he replied. “This man told me he belonged to the police, that he was a detective, and told him to keep quiet.

Sentences_from: Pędził co tchu, wymachiwał rękoma, a gdy się z nimi zrównał -- tupał nogami i zapewne krzyczał i robił wymówki sir Henrykowi. Ten widocznie usprawiedliwiał się.
Sentences_to: I ran down the hill therefore and met the baronet at the bottom. His face was flushed with anger and his brows were wrinkled, like one who is at his wit's ends what to do.
Translated_sentences: He would rush every breath, wave his arms, and as he aligned with them — stomp his feet and probably scream and make excuses to Sir Henry. This one was evidently justifying itself.

Sentences_from: -- Nie daruję sobie nigdy, żem go zostawił samego... -- szepnąłem.
Sentences_to: "The brute! the brute!" I cried with clenched hands. "Oh Holmes, I shall never forgive myself for having left him to his fate."
Translated_sentences: “I never give myself that he left him alone...” I whispered.

Sentences_from: Z dnia na dzień spodziewaliśmy się, że opuści te strony, lecz dopóki tu jest, my nie możemy go opuścić. Jeżeli kto zawinił, to ja, nie mój mąż; on go ukrywał i żywił, przez wzgląd na mnie...
Sentences_to: Every day we hoped that he was gone, but as long as he was there we could not desert him. That is the whole truth, as I am an honest Christian woman, and you will see that if there is blame in the matter it does not lie with my husband, but with me, for whose sake he has done all that he has."
Translated_sentences: We expected him to leave these sites overnight, but as long as he is here, we cannot leave him. If who wrap it, it was me, not my husband; he hid it and fed it, for the sake of me...

Sentences_from: -- Poprostu sprzyjamy i dopomagamy łotrowi...
Sentences_to: "I guess we are aiding and abetting a felony, Watson?
Translated_sentences: - We just favor and help the rogue...

Sentences_from: -- Poczekamy tutaj -- szepnął. -- Te kamienie na prawo stanowią wyborną osłonę.
Sentences_to: "This will do," said he. "These rocks upon the right make an admirable screen."
Translated_sentences: “We will wait here,” he whispered. “These stones to the right constitute a choice of cover.

Sentences_from: Nie miałem tak miłego dnia od chwili, gdym pozwał sir Johna Morland o bezprawne polowanie w jego własnym lesie.
Sentences_to: I told the police last time they did it that they should stop these disgraceful exhibitions.
Translated_sentences: I haven't had such a nice day since the moment, gdym sued Sir John Morland for unlawful hunting in his own woods.

Sentences_from: -- Widzę, że pan przejął się tą stratą.
Sentences_to: "I just don't attempt to explain it.
Translated_sentences: - I see you took care of this loss.

Sentences_from: Pozostawało tylko sprawdzić, czy istotnie w owym czasie przedsięwzięła kroki rozwodowe.
Sentences_to: I could only check it by finding if she had, indeed, instituted divorce proceedings against her husband at or about the time of the tragedy.
Translated_sentences: It remained only to see if she had taken divorce steps at that time.

Sentences_from: Musisz chyba przyznać, że niema w tem nic nadnaturalnego.
Sentences_to: You must allow that there is nothing supernatural about this, at any rate?"
Translated_sentences: I think you have to admit that there's nothing supernatural about it.

Sentences_from: -- Jeżeli widywał panią tak rzadko i otrzymywał od pani nieczęste listy, skądże mógł być do tego stopnia poinformowany o jej interesach, aby przychodzić jej z pomocą, jak to pani sama zeznała?
Sentences_to: "But if you saw him so seldom and wrote so seldom, how did he know enough about your affairs to be able to help you, as you say that he has done?"
Translated_sentences: — If he had seen you so rarely and received infrequent letters from you, he could have been informed of her interests to come to her aid, how did you testify yourself?

Sentences_from: Tajemniczy nieznajomy, nie mogąc sam mnie tropić, polecił to owemu chłopcu. Ten donosił mu zapewne o każdym moim kroku.
Sentences_to: Possibly I had taken no step since I had been upon the moor which had not been observed and reported. Always there was this feeling of an unseen force, a fine net drawn round us with infinite skill and delicacy, holding us so lightly that it was only at some supreme moment that one realized that one was indeed entangled in its meshes.
Translated_sentences: A mysterious stranger, unable to track me down himself, recommended this to this boy. This one probably reported to him every step of my own.

Sentences_from: -- Wszak pan wie, co mi polecił Holmes...
Sentences_to: "Well, you know what my instructions are.
Translated_sentences: - After all, you know what Holmes instructed me...

Sentences_from: Widok był na trawnik przed portykiem.
Sentences_to: It opened upon the grassy space which lay in front of the hall door.
Translated_sentences: The view was of the lawn in front of the portico.

Sentences_from: Na pierwszej stronicy był nagłówek: „Baskerville Hall”, a pod spodem data: „1742”.
Sentences_to: At the head was written: "Baskerville Hall," and below in large, scrawling figures: "1742."
Translated_sentences: On the front page was the headline: “Baskerville Hall,” and underneath the date: “1742.”

Sentences_from: Z pośród wielu Mortimerów, jeden tylko mógł być tym, o którego nam chodziło.
Sentences_to: There were several Mortimers, but only one who could be our visitor.
Translated_sentences: Of the many Mortimers, one only could have been the one we meant.

Sentences_from: -- Pani się myli -- rzekłem. -- Jestem tylko jego przyjacielem.
Sentences_to: "No, no," said I. "Only a humble commoner, but his friend.
Translated_sentences: “You're wrong,” I said. “I'm just his friend.

Sentences_from: -- On nie napadnie na żaden dom.
Sentences_to: "He'll break into no house, sir. I give you my solemn word upon that.
Translated_sentences: - He's not raiding any house.

Sentences_from: Rozległo się miarowe stąpanie. Kroki stawały się coraz głośniejsze i wyraźniejsze, dochodziły do nas przez mgłę, jak przez zasłonę, i oto nagle pojawił się ten, na którego czekaliśmy.
Sentences_to: So as the fog-bank flowed onward we fell back before it until we were half a mile from the house, and still that dense white sea, with the moon silvering its upper edge, swept slowly and inexorably on.
Translated_sentences: There's been a measuring scramble. The steps were getting louder and clearer, coming to us through the fog, like through the veil, and here was suddenly the one we were waiting for.

Sentences_from: Nie myśl, że to było złudzenie zmysłów. O ile mogłem zauważyć, był to mężczyzna wysokiego wzrostu, szczupły.
Sentences_to: There, outlined as black as an ebony statue on that shining back-ground, I saw the figure of a man upon the tor.
Translated_sentences: Don't think it was a sense delusion. As far as I could notice, it was a man of high stature, slim.

Sentences_from: Jeśli nam się nie uda wyświetlić sprawy, cała odpowiedzialność spadnie na pana.
Sentences_to: Oh, Dr. Mortimer, Dr. Mortimer, to think that you should not have called me in! You have indeed much to answer for."
Translated_sentences: If we fail to display the case, all responsibility will fall on you.

Sentences_from: Usiadłem na łóżku i począłem nasłuchiwać.
Sentences_to: It was the sob of a woman, the muffled, strangling gasp of one who is torn by an uncontrollable sorrow. I sat up in bed and listened intently.
Translated_sentences: I sat on the bed and felt to listen.

Sentences_from: Możnaby sądzić, że taki maryaż powinien być mile widzianym przez Stapletona, jednak spostrzegam niezadowolenie na jego twarzy, ilekroć sir Henryk zbliża się do jego siostry, lub okazuje swój zachwyt. Tłómaczę to sobie egoistycznem przywiązaniem, bo życie przyrodnika na tem pustkowiu byłoby jeszcze smutniejsze, gdyby go nie opromieniała miss Beryl.
Sentences_to: They dine here to-night, and there is some talk of our going to them next week. One would imagine that such a match would be very welcome to Stapleton, and yet I have more than once caught a look of the strongest disapprobation in his face when Sir Henry has been paying some attention to his sister.
Translated_sentences: One might think that such a maryage should be welcomed by Stapleton, however, I see the discontent on his face whenever Sir Henry approaches his sister, or shows his delight. I find this egotistical attachment to myself, because the life of a naturalist in this wasteland would be even sadder if he wasn't radiated by Beryl's miss.

Sentences_from: Ten blady mężczyzna z czarną brodą wydawał mi się podejrzanym.
Sentences_to: Yet he had taken the obvious risk of discovery in declaring that it was not so. Why had he done this?
Translated_sentences: That pale man with a black beard seemed like a suspect to me.

Sentences_from: Podniósł się trzymając w ręku stary but.
Sentences_to: He held an old black boot in the air.
Translated_sentences: He picked himself up holding an old shoe in his hand.

Sentences_from: -- No i cóż, czy Seldon opuścił już te strony? -- rzekłem -- czy jeszcze grasuje?
Sentences_to: "Well," said I, "has this precious relation of yours departed, or is he still lurking out yonder?"
Translated_sentences: - Well, has Seldon left these sites yet? - I said, is he still prowling?

Sentences_from: (To są przestrogi Hugona Baskerville, spisane dla jego synów, Rogera i Jana, z rozkazem, aby o tem wszystkiem nie wspominali swej siostrze, Elżbiecie).
Sentences_to: "[This from Hugo Baskerville to his sons Rodger and John, with instructions that they say nothing thereof to their sister Elizabeth.]"
Translated_sentences: (These are the cautions of Hugon Baskerville, written down for his sons, Roger and John, with orders that they should not mention it all to their sister, Elizabeth.)

Sentences_from: W oczach kobiety bywają błyski, wymowniejsze od słów.
Sentences_to: But he has never let us get together, and it was only to-day for the first time that I saw a chance of having a few words with her alone.
Translated_sentences: There are flashes in the eyes of a woman, eloquent than words.

Sentences_from: Zdaje mi się, że ujrzał istotnie jakieś dziwne stworzenie w Alei Wiązów...
Sentences_to: I fancy that he really did see something of the kind upon that last night in the Yew Alley.
Translated_sentences: I think he saw a very strange creature in Elm Avenue...

Sentences_from: Tam, w tej jaskini jest klucz do tajemnicy.
Sentences_to: There, in that hut upon the moor, seems to lie the very centre of that problem which has vexed me so sorely.
Translated_sentences: There in this cave is the key to the mystery.

Sentences_from: Przypuściwszy, że jakie nieszczęście spotka naszego przyjaciela -- daruj mi pan tę smutną hypotezę -- kto wówczas odziedziczy majątek?
Sentences_to: Supposing that anything happened to our young friend here--you will forgive the unpleasant hypothesis!--who would inherit the estate?"
Translated_sentences: Supposing that what misfortune will befall our friend — give me this sad hypothesis — who will inherit the estate then?

Sentences_from: Ten ostatni był niewielkiego wzrostu, silnie zbudowany, miał lat ze trzydzieści, włosy i oczy ciemne; gęste czarne brwi nadawały jego twarzy wyraz stanowczy, a nawet srogi. Z całej jego postawy i ogorzałego oblicza było znać, że dużo przebywał na świeżem powietrzu; wyglądał na skończonego gentlemana.
Sentences_to: The latter was a small, alert, dark-eyed man about thirty years of age, very sturdily built, with thick black eyebrows and a strong, pugnacious face. Sentences_from: Bądź co bądź, trudno mi będzie teraz spełnić twoje polecenie: abym nigdy nie opuszczał sir Henryka. Sprzykrzyłbym mu się prędko, gdybym chodził za nim, jak cień.
Sentences_to: Yet I am certain that he does not wish their intimacy to ripen into love, and I have several times observed that he has taken pains to prevent them from being tˆte-…-tˆte.

Sentences_from: Nie zdziwiłbym się, gdyby ten głos był wabieniem ostatniego bąka w Europie.

Sentences_from: Śmierć sir Karola pozostała niewyjaśniona; władze policyjne łamały sobie głowę nad jej przyczyną, okolica była w strachu, wreszcie oddano sprawę w nasze ręce.
Sentences_to: "So much for the death of Sir Charles Baskerville. You perceive the devilish cunning of it, for really it would be almost impossible to make a case against the real murderer.

Sentences_from: Wiedziałem, że jest chory na serce i że ciągły niepokój źle wpływa na jego zdrowie.

Sentences_from: Barrymore, zaniósłszy kuferki do naszych pokojów, wrócił i stał przy drzwiach, jako wytrawny służbista, nie chcąc przerywać naszej rozmowy. Był to mężczyzna lat średnich, niezwykłej urody, o twarzy bladej, z dużą czarną brodą i regularnymi rysami.
Sentences_to: I saw his dark face lit up with a boyish enthusiasm as he gazed about him. The light beat upon him where he stood, but long shadows trailed down the walls and hung like a black canopy above him. Barrymore had returned from taking our luggage to our rooms. He stood in front of us now with the subdued manner of a well-trained servant. He was a remarkable-looking man, tall, handsome, with a square black beard and pale, distinguished features.
Translated_sentences: Barrymore, understated a pint to our rooms, returned and stood at the door, as a consummate servant, unwilling to interrupt our conversation. It was a man of middle years, of unusual beauty, face pale, with a large black beard and regular features.

Sentences_from: Przyznaję, że moja w tem wina: trzeba było poprowadzić sprawę inaczej i oszczędzić naszemu klientowi tej przykrości, ale nie mogłem przewidzieć, że ten łotr posmaruje psa siarką i że owej nocy będzie mgła, dzięki czemu sir Henryk nie mógł widzieć z oddali czworonożnego sprzymierzeńca Stapletona, który wyskoczył znienacka i przestraszył tego odważnego człowieka.
Sentences_to: That Sir Henry should have been exposed to this is, I must confess, a reproach to my management of the case, but we had no means of foreseeing the terrible and paralyzing spectacle which the beast presented, nor could we predict the fog which enabled him to burst upon us at such short notice. We succeeded in our object at a cost which both the specialist and Dr. Mortimer assure me will be a temporary one.
Translated_sentences: I acknowledge my fault: it was necessary to lead the case differently and spare our client this delight, but I could not foresee that this villain would smear the dog with sulfur and that there would be fog that night, so that Sir Henry could not see Stapleton's four-legged ally from the distance, who jumped out and frightened this brave man.

Sentences_from: -- Mieszkam tu od lat dwóch zaledwie.

Sentences_from: Jako Stapleton, z resztkami ukradzionych pieniędzy, z pięknymi zbiorami entomologicznymi przesiedlił się do Anglii południowej.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli ma go opuścić, to on, Stapleton, woli, żeby poślubiła sąsiada, mieszkającego tak blizko, niż kogokolwiek innego. Ale musi oswoić się z tą myślą.
Sentences_to: If she had to leave him he had rather it was to a neighbour like myself than to anyone else. But in any case it was a blow to him, and it would take him some time before he could prepare himself to meet it.

Sentences_from: Ponieważ się spóźniał, wyszedłem na jego spotkanie i wtedy usłyszałem okrzyk...

Sentences_from: Przez chwilę siedziałem z zapartym oddechem, oczom własnym nie wierząc, wreszcie odzyskałem głos, powróciła mi przytomność, a jednocześnie spadł z serca kamień odpowiedzialności.
Sentences_to: For a moment or two I sat breathless, hardly able to believe my ears. Then my senses and my voice came back to me, while a crushing weight of responsibility seemed in an instant to be lifted from my soul.
Translated_sentences: For a moment I sat with bated breath, my eyes not believing, finally regained my voice, returned my consciousness, and at the same time a stone of responsibility fell from my heart.

Sentences_from: Przed wieczorem będziemy wiedzieli, czy Barrymore jest na swojem stanowisku w Devonshire.

Translated_sentences: Sir Charles was secretive, taciturn. We approached because of his illness, we were connected by common scientific tastes.

Sentences_from: -- Dla bardzo prostej przyczyny, że mam tego psa przed oczyma; stoi za temi drzwiami, a jego właściciel w tej chwili właśnie do nich dzwoni.

Sentences_from: Badacze kryminologii pamiętają podobny wypadek w roku 1866 w Grodnie, a drugi w północnej Karolinie w roku 1878, ale obecny fakt ma swoje odrębności. I teraz nawet, po wykryciu szczegółów, nie wiem jeszcze, w jaki sposób Stapleton przyczynił się do śmierci sir Karola.
Sentences_to: Students of criminology will remember the analogous incidents in Godno, in Little Russia, in the year '66, and of course there are the Anderson murders in North Carolina, but this case possesses some features which are entirely its own. Even now we have no clear case against this very wily man.
Translated_sentences: Criminology researchers remember a similar accident in 1866 in Grodno and another in North Carolina in 1878, but the present fact has its own distinctions. And now even, having detected the details, I do not yet know how Stapleton contributed to Sir Charles's death.

Sentences_from: Naraziło mnie to na dużą stratę pieniężną; ale żal mi tylko zmarłych dzieci; dla siebie nie żałuję tego, bo mam czas oddawać się moim ulubionym badaniom i znalazłem tu obfite pole do studyów nad botaniką i zoologią. Siostra dzieli moje upodobania przyrodnicze.
Sentences_to: And yet, if it were not for the loss of the charming companionship of the boys, I could rejoice over my own misfortune, for, with my strong tastes for botany and zoology, I find an unlimited field of work here, and my sister is as devoted to Nature as I am.
Translated_sentences: It exposed me to a large monetary loss; but I only feel sorry for the dead children; for myself, I don't regret it, for I have time to indulge in my favorite research, and I found a plentiful field here for study on botany and zoology. Sister shares my natural tastes.

Sentences_from: Przekonywam się coraz bardziej, że jesteś pan szpiegowany tutaj, a wśród milionów ludzi, nagromadzonych w stolicy, trudno jest wykryć tych pańskich prześladowców, czy opiekunów.
Sentences_to: I have ample evidence that you are being dogged in London, and amid the millions of this great city it is difficult to discover who these people are or what their object can be.
Translated_sentences: I find myself more and more that you are being spied on here, and among the millions of people accumulated in the capital, it is difficult to detect those abusers of yours, or carers.

Sentences_from: W dzisiejszej epoce parweniuszów miło jest widzieć potomka starożytnego a podupadłego rodu, odzyskującego fortunę swych przodków i przywracającego świetność staremu nazwisku.
Sentences_to: More wise than those who go on until the wheel turns against them, he realized his gains and returned to England with them. It is only two years since he took up his residence at Baskerville Hall, and it is common talk how large were those schemes of reconstruction and improvement which have been interrupted by his death.
Translated_sentences: In today's Parvenius age, it is nice to see a descendant of an ancient and a fallen lineage regaining the fortune of his ancestors and restoring his greatness to his old name.

Sentences_from: Upadał coraz niżej, wreszcie spełnił tę ostatnią zbrodnię... Ale dla mnie jest on zawsze małym chłopaczkiem z jasnymi kędziorami, którego niańczyłam, jako starsza siostra.
Sentences_to: From crime to crime he sank lower and lower, until it is only the mercy of God which has snatched him from the scaffold; but to me, sir, he was always the little curly-headed boy that I had nursed and played with, as an elder sister would.
Translated_sentences: He was falling lower and lower, finally fulfilling this latest crime... But to me, he is always a little boy with bright curlers, whom I used to babysitter, as a big sister.

Sentences_from: Są poszlaki, że już był wylękniony, zanim począł uciekać.

Sentences_from: Patrząc przez okno na te bagna, usiane kamieniami, zastanawiałem się, co mogło skłonić tak wykształconego mężczyznę i tak piękną kobietę do obrania tutaj siedziby.
Sentences_to: As I looked from their windows at the interminable granite-flecked moor rolling unbroken to the farthest horizon I could not but marvel at what could have brought this highly educated man and this beautiful woman to live in such a place.

Sentences_from: Przywiózł wiele ciekawych wiadomości z Afryki Południowej. Spędziliśmy niejeden miły wieczór na rozprawach o anatomii porównawczej.
Sentences_to: He had brought back much scientific information from South Africa, and many a charming evening we have spent together discussing the comparative anatomy of the Bushman and the Hottentot.

Sentences_from: Dotychczas jednak nie przywiązywałem wagi do tej legendy.

Sentences_from: Do uszu jej doszła wieść o nagłej śmierci zbiegłego więźnia na moczarach, a że wiedziała, iż pies trzymany jest tam na uwięzi, domyśliła się, jaką śmierć Stapleton gotuje sir Henrykowi, tembardziej, gdy mąż przyprowadził psa i zamknął go w oficynie.
Sentences_to: She had learned something of the death of the convict, and she knew that the hound was being kept in the out-house on the evening that Sir Henry was coming to dinner. Sentences_from: -- A teraz, zechciej mi pan powiedzieć, doktorze Mortimer -- będzie to szczegół ważny -- czy ślady, któreś pan spostrzegł, pozostały na żwirze, czy na trawie?

Sentences_from: Cały dom spowity w gęstą mgłę; to się podnosi, to opada, ukazując łąkę i trzęsawisko.

Translated_sentences: The room was a kind of museum; in display cases and on the walls were unbuttoned rare butterfly specimens.

Sentences_from: Nasz przyjazd był widocznie wypadkiem dnia, gdyż obstąpili nas tragarze, a naczelnik stacyi ze swoim sztabem przyglądali nam się ciekawie.
Sentences_to: It was a sweet, simple country spot, but I was surprised to observe that by the gate there stood two soldierly men in dark uniforms, who leaned upon their short rifles and glanced keenly at us as we passed. The coachman, a hard-faced, gnarled little fellow, saluted Sir Henry Baskerville, and in a few minutes we were flying swiftly down the broad, white road.
Translated_sentences: Our arrival was evidently the accident of the day, as the porters came to us, and the warden stacya with his staff looked at us interestingly.

Sentences_from: Zaczynam więc od dnia, następującego po tym, w którym wykryłem dwa bardzo ważne fakty: a więc naprzód, że pani Laura Lyons z Coombe-Tracey pisała do sir Karola Baskerville i wyznaczyła mu spotkanie o godzinie, w której śmierć znalazł; powtóre, że człowiek, przebywający na bagnie, ukrywa się w jednej z jaskiń na stoku góry.
Sentences_to: I start then from the day which succeeded that upon which I had established two facts of great importance, the one that Mrs. Laura Lyons of Coombe Tracey had written to Sir Charles Baskerville and made an appointment with him at the very place and hour that he met his death, the other that the lurking man upon the moor was to be found among the stone huts upon the hill-side.

Sentences_from: Jak wryty w ziemię, stał żołnierz na koniu, z bagnetem przez ramię.

Sentences_from: Człowiek przedhistoryczny zaludniał gęsto te bagna, a ponieważ od tych czasów nikt tu nie mieszkał, ich jaskinie pozostały nietknięte.
Sentences_to: Prehistoric man lived thickly on the moor, and as no one in particular has lived there since, we find all his little arrangements exactly as he left them. These are his wigwams with the roofs off.
Translated_sentences: Prehistoric man populated these marshes densely, and since no one has lived here since these times, their caves remained intact.

Sentences_from: -- Doniesiono mi z policyi, że ktoś, mieszkający pod tym adresem, wypytuje o Nr. 2704 -- rzekł ów człowiek o twarzy dobrodusznej. -- Jeżdżę już siedem lat i nikt na mnie nigdy skargi nie wnosił, więc bardzo mnie to zadziwiło i przyjechałem, żeby się dowiedzieć, co pan ma przeciwko mnie.
Sentences_to: "I got a message from the head office that a gent at this address had been inquiring for 2704," said he. "I've driven my cab this seven years and never a word of complaint. I came here straight from the Yard to ask you to your face what you had against me."
Translated_sentences: “It was reported to me from the police that someone living at this address was asking about No. 2704 — said this man with a good-natured face. “I've been driving seven years now and no one has ever complained about me, so it amazed me a lot and I came to find out what you have against me.

Sentences_from: -- Czyżeś pan nie oglądał ziemi dokoła?

Sentences_from: Ma obecnie siedem procesów, które zapewne pochłoną resztę jego fortuny. Po za tą manią wydaje się dobrodusznym, poczciwym staruszkiem; wspominam o nim dlatego tylko, żeś mi polecił opisywać ci wszystkie osoby, które spotykam i o których słyszę.

Apart from the law he seems a kindly, good-natured person, and I only mention him because you were particular that I should send some description of the people who surround us.

Sentences_from: -- Spostrzegłem to odrazu, gdyś pan wszedł do pokoju -- odparł Holmes.

Sentences_from: Odwróciłem się, pewien, że ujrzę doktora Mortimer, lecz ku mojemu zdziwieniu, zobaczyłem nieznajomego. Był to mężczyzna niewielkiego wzrostu, o twarzy wygolonej, o włosach ciemnych, gładko przyczesanych; mógł mieć lat trzydzieści parę do czterdziestu.
Sentences_to: "Your net and box would have told me as much," said I, "for I knew that Mr. Stapleton was a naturalist.

Sentences_from: Minęliśmy ciemną aleję, i szerokim, wzniesionym podjazdem zajechaliśmy przed pałac. Środkowy korpus ozdobiony był wspaniałym portykiem; po bokach wznosiły się wieże, średniowieczne, zębate, ze strzelnicami.
Sentences_to: The avenue opened into a broad expanse of turf, and the house lay before us. In the fading light I could see that the centre was a heavy block of building from which a porch projected. The whole front was draped in ivy, with a patch clipped bare here and there where a window or a coat-of-arms broke through the dark veil. >From this central block rose the twin towers, ancient, crenelated, and pierced with many loopholes. To right and left of the turrets were more modern wings of black granite. A dull light shone through heavy mullioned windows, and from the high chimneys which rose from the steep, high-angled roof there sprang a single black column of smoke.
Translated_sentences: We passed a dark avenue, and in a wide, elevated driveway we came in front of the palace. The middle body was decorated with a magnificent portico; towers, medieval, toothed, with shooting ranges, were erected on the sides.

Sentences_from: Jak wielu mądrych zbrodniarzy, jest zapewne zbyt zaufany w swoim rozumie i wyobraża sobie, że nas w pole wywiedzie.
Sentences_to: Like most clever criminals, he may be too confident in his own cleverness and imagine that he has completely deceived us."
Translated_sentences: Like many smart criminals, he is probably too trusted in his understandings and imagines that he will leave us in the field.

Sentences_from: Sir Henryk i doktor Mortimer bawili w Londynie, gotując się do dalekiej podróży, która miała wzmocnić nerwy baroneta.
Sentences_to: Sir Henry and Dr. Mortimer were, however, in London, on their way to that long voyage which had been recommended for the restoration of his shattered nerves. They had called upon us that very afternoon, so that it was natural that the subject should come up for discussion.
Translated_sentences: Sir Henry and Dr Mortimer entertained in London, boiling for a far-flung journey that was to strengthen the baronet's nerves.

Sentences_from: Dom, przerobiony widocznie ze starej fermy, wznosił się wśród drzew niewielkich, otoczony był murowanym parkanom; wyglądał smutno i ponuro.

Sentences_from: -- Ha! nie jest to miła robota, zwłaszcza wśród takiego otoczenia. Cóż za pustkowie!... -- mówił Lestrade, oglądając się dokoła.
Sentences_to: "My word, it does not seem a very cheerful place," said the detective with a shiver, glancing round him at the gloomy slopes of the hill and at the huge lake of fog which lay over the Grimpen Mire. "I see the lights of a house ahead of us."

Sentences_to: "Yes, sir, my name was Selden, and he is my younger brother. We humoured him too much when he was a lad, and gave him his own way in everything until he came to think that the world was made for his pleasure, and that he could do what he liked in it.

Sentences_from: Były to jedyne oznaki życia; dokoła pustka i cisza, nigdzie nie mogłem dojrzeć śladów owej postaci widmowej, którą dostrzegłem parę dni temu.

Sentences_to: He wanted to know the object of my inquiries, but I managed to satisfy his curiosity without telling him too much, for there is no reason why we should take anyone into our confidence.

Sentences_from: -- Istotnie, Watson, przechodzisz sam siebie -- rzekł Holmes, zapalając papierosa. -- Muszę przyznać, że pańskie wnioski są słuszne.

Sentences_to: There he sat, with his tweed suit and his American accent, in the corner of a prosaic railway-carriage, and yet as I looked at his dark and expressive face I felt more than ever how true a descendant he was of that long line of high-blooded, fiery, and masterful men. There were pride, valour, and strength in his thick brows, his sensitive nostrils, and his large hazel eyes.
Translated_sentences: Baskerville looked at him with a shrug, as a fight where the tragic fortunes of his family played out.

Sentences_to: Between us we soon supplied his wants, and then over a belated supper we explained to the baronet as much of our experience as it seemed desirable that he should know.

Sentences_to: He therefore put pressure upon Mrs. Lyons to write this letter, imploring the old man to give her an interview on the evening before his departure for London. He then, by a specious argument, prevented her from going, and so had the chance for which he had waited.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne to trzęsawisko -- mówił, wskazując mi olbrzymią płaszczyznę, pokrytą piaskami i trawą -- dla nieoswojonego oka wydaje się monotonnem i smutnem, ale kto się przyzwyczai do tych fal piaszczystych; dla tego mają one urok nieprzeparty, a zawierają tyle tajemnic!...
Sentences_to: "It is a wonderful place, the moor," said he, looking round over the undulating downs, long green rollers, with crests of jagged granite foaming up into fantastic surges. "You never tire of the moor. You cannot think the wonderful secrets which it contains. It is so vast, and so barren, and so mysterious."

Sentences_from: Słyszeliśmy przed sobą warczenie psa i wołanie o pomoc sir Henryka.
Sentences_to: I am reckoned fleet of foot, but he outpaced me as much as I outpaced the little professional.

Sentences_from: -- Czy Barrymore został wymieniony w testamencie sir Karola? -- pytał Holmes.
Sentences_to: "Did Barrymore profit at all by Sir Charles's will?" asked Holmes.

Sentences_from: Oboje z bratem zmartwiliśmy się bardzo śmiercią sir Karola.
Sentences_to: "My brother and I were very much shocked by the death of Sir Charles.

Sentences_from: -- Czy to było tutaj?... -- spytał półgłosem.

Sentences_from: Patrz, rzuciłeś niedopalony papieros, zapewne w chwili, gdyś zdecydował się wejść do tej jaskini.

Translated_sentences: Look, you threw an undershot cigarette, probably the moment he decided to enter this cave.

Sentences_from: Osiedliliśmy się tutaj wkrótce po przybyciu sir Karola, ale moje upodobania przyrodnicze skłaniają mnie do ciągłych wędrówek, to też poznałem każdą niemal piędź ziemi. Sądzę, że nikt tutaj nie zna jej lepiej odemnie.
Sentences_to: We came shortly after Sir Charles settled. But my tastes led me to explore every part of the country round, and I should think that there are few men who know it better than I do."
Translated_sentences: We settled here soon after Sir Charles arrived, but my natural tastes prompt me to keep hiking, I too have come to know every near-sink of the earth. I don't think anyone here knows her better than that.

Sentences_from: Nawet zamach na sir Henryka, który skończył się śmiercią Seldona, nieszczęsnego więźnia, nie mógł nam pomódz do wykazania zbrodniczości Stapletona.
Sentences_to: "By the time that you discovered me upon the moor I had a complete knowledge of the whole business, but I had not a case which could go to a jury. Even Stapleton's attempt upon Sir Henry that night which ended in the death of the unfortunate convict did not help us much in proving murder against our man.
Translated_sentences: Even the assassination of Sir Henry, which ended in the death of Seldon, a hapless prisoner, could not help us to demonstrate Stapleton's criminality.

Sentences_from: Miałem ochotę odmówić ze względu na sir Henryka, ale przypomniałem sobie, że jest zajęty korespondencyą; nie mogłem mu dopomódz, a z drugiej strony, Holmes kazał mi poznawać sąsiedztwo. Więc przyjąłem zaproszenie pana Stapleton i weszliśmy razem na ścieżkę.
Sentences_to: My first thought was that I should be by Sir Henry's side. But then I remembered the pile of papers and bills with which his study table was littered. It was certain that I could not help with those. And Holmes had expressly said that I should study the neighbours upon the moor. I accepted Stapleton's invitation, and we turned together down the path.
Translated_sentences: I felt like saying no for Sir Henry's sake, but I remembered that he was busy with correspondence; I couldn't help him, and on the other hand, Holmes told me to explore the neighborhood. So I accepted Mr. Stapleton's invitation and we walked on the path together.

Sentences_from: Jedną z wad Sherlocka Holmes -- jeśli można to nazwać wadą -- jest skrytość.
Sentences_to: One of Sherlock Holmes's defects--if, indeed, one may call it a defect--was that he was exceedingly loath to communicate his full plans to any other person until the instant of their fulfilment.
Translated_sentences: One of the drawbacks of Sherlock Holmes — if you can call it a flaw — is secretness.

Sentences_from: Dowodzenie było bardzo logiczne. -- Bezwątpienia -- odparłem -- ale skąd pan wie, że on kryje się na bagnie?
Sentences_to: He certainly seemed to be getting uncomfortably near the truth. "No doubt," said I; "but how do you know that he is anywhere upon the moor?"
Translated_sentences: The command was very logical. — Doubtless — I rebutted — but how do you know that he's in the swamp?

Sentences_from: Żona domyślała się jego planów, lecz obawiała się ostrzedz upatrzoną ofiarę.
Sentences_to: If the letter should fall into Stapleton's hands her own life would not be safe.

Sentences_from: Wzruszyłem ramionami. -- Jeżeli istotnie ma opuścić Anglię, uwolni to kraj od utrzymywania jednego więcej łotra -- odrzekłem.
Sentences_to: I shrugged my shoulders. "If he were safely out of the country it would relieve the tax-payer of a burden."
Translated_sentences: I shrugged my shoulders. — If it is indeed to leave England, it will free the country from keeping one more rogue — I said no.

Sentences_from: Pozwoli mi pan, panie Holmes, zbadać swoją czaszkę.

Sentences_from: Nie mówiliśmy o tej sprawie, dopiero gdyśmy wrócili do apartamentu sir Henryka, oznajmił nam swoją decyzyę.
Sentences_to: It was in the private sitting-room to which we afterwards repaired that Holmes asked Baskerville what were his intentions.
Translated_sentences: We did not talk about this matter, it was until we returned to Sir Henry's suite that he would tell us his decision.

Sentences_from: Holmes za pośrednictwem baroneta chciał przekonać Stapletonów, żeśmy wyjechali istotnie, a my tymczasem zjawimy się w chwili grożącego niebezpieczeństwa.
Sentences_to: He would use the baronet in order to convince the Stapletons that we were really gone, while we should actually return at the instant when we were likely to be needed.
Translated_sentences: Holmes, through the baronet, wanted to convince the Stapletons that we would leave materially, and we would, meanwhile, come in a moment of danger.

Sentences_from: Nie było w nich namiętności, lecz niezłomna, okrutna wola; tryskała ona z oczu stalowych, zdradzały ją usta wązkie, zaciśnięte.
Sentences_to: It was not a brutal countenance, but it was prim, hard, and stern, with a firm-set, thin-lipped mouth, and a coldly intolerant eye.
Translated_sentences: There was no passion in them, but a steadfast, cruel will; it squirted from the eyes of steel; it was betrayed by its lips, clenched.

Sentences_from: -- Przeklęta mgła! -- mruczał Holmes. -- Ogarnie nas niebawem, a wtedy wszystko stracone.
Sentences_to: The night was clear and fine above us. The stars shone cold and bright, while a half-moon bathed the whole scene in a soft, uncertain light.
Translated_sentences: - Damn fog! - Holmes muttered. — He'll scuttle us soon, and then all lost.

Sentences_from: -- Dziwne te bagna, prawda? -- rzekł jakby z dumą.

Sentences_from: Zapisani są w księgach zakładu fotograficznego jako „państwo Vandelour”, ale łatwo poznać i ją, i jego.

Sentences_from: Chciałbym się dowiedzieć o tem, co ukrywaliście przedemną.

Sentences_from: -- Słuchaj, Barrymore -- rzekłem. -- Przybyłem tu w interesie twojego pana.

Sentences_from: Sprawa nieczysta. Możemy się śmiać, ale ci powiem, że chciałbym cię już widzieć tutaj z powrotem.

Sentences_from: Od owego punktu, rząd wetkniętych w błoto gałęzi wskazywał kępki ziemi, po których można było przejść suchą nogą.
Sentences_to: It helped us to realize the horror of this woman's life when we saw the eagerness and joy with which she laid us on her husband's track. We left her standing upon the thin peninsula of firm, peaty soil which tapered out into the widespread bog.

Sentences_from: Stanął przed detektywem w postawie pełnej uszanowania.

Sentences_from: -- Czy on robi na tobie wrażenie waryata?

Sentences_from: -- Bądź co bądź, wyszłaś pani z tej sprawy obronną ręką -- przekładał jej Holmes. -- Miałaś go pani w swej mocy, a jednak żyjesz.
Sentences_to: "I think that on the whole you have had a fortunate escape," said Sherlock Holmes. "You have had him in your power and he knew it, and yet you are alive.
Translated_sentences: You left this case with a defensive hand — Holmes put her through. — You had him in your power, and yet you're alive.

Sentences_from: Studya nad portretami rodzinnymi mogą nas przejąć wiarą w wędrówkę dusz.

Sentences_from: -- Mrs. Lyons -- rzekłem, wstając -- bierze pani na siebie wielką odpowiedzialność i stawia się pani w trudnem położeniu.
Sentences_to: "Mrs. Lyons," said I, as I rose from this long and inconclusive interview, "you are taking a very great responsibility and putting yourself in a very false position by not making an absolutely clean breast of all that you know.

Sentences_from: Jeżeli potrafię wydobyć z niego więcej faktów, oszczędzi mi to czasu i trudu.

Sentences_from: -- Oby wszystkie przykrości zostały równie szybko usunięte -- życzył mu Sherlock Holmes.

Sentences_from: -- Naturalnie, pisywałam do niego, aby mu podziękować za jego delikatność i wspaniałomyślność.

Translated_sentences: - Naturally, I wrote to him to thank him for his delicacy and awesomeness.

Sentences_from: Pociąganoby pana do odpowiedzialności za to, że, znając kryjówkę zbiegłego więźnia, nie uwiadomiłeś o niej policyi...

Sentences_from: Gdybym zdołał go schwytać, możeby to wyjaśniło wszystkie te zagadki. Całą moją energię wytężę, aby tego celu dopiąć.

Sentences_from: Na progu stała pani Barrymore, jeszcze bledsza od męża.

Sentences_from: Zastanowił mnie widok dwóch rosłych chłopów w mundurach żołnierskich; stali, oparci na karabinach i nie spuszczali z nas oka.
Sentences_to: Rolling pasture lands curved upward on either side of us, and old gabled houses peeped out from amid the thick green foliage, but behind the peaceful and sunlit country-side there rose ever, dark against the evening sky, the long, gloomy curve of the moor, broken by the jagged and sinister hills.

Sentences_from: Ani słowa przed nim o naszych podejrzeniach... ani słowa! bo inaczej, wszystkie moje plany pójdą w niwecz. Ujrzałem światełko cygara.
Sentences_to: It's the man himself, by all that's wonderful and audacious!

Sentences_from: Pani Stapleton zeznaje, iż jej mąż miał w tym względzie kilka projektów: albo upomnieć się o sukcesyę z Ameryki południowej i tam dowieść swej tożsamości i uzyskać fortunę, nie przyjeżdżając do Anglii; albo dostarczyć jakiemu wspólnikowi potrzebnych legitymacyj i za jego pośrednictwem spadek otrzymać; albo prowadzić sam sprawę na miejscu, lecz pod inną postacią zewnętrzną, w takiem przebraniu, żeby nikt poznać go nie mógł.
Sentences_to: "It is a formidable difficulty, and I fear that you ask too much when you expect me to solve it. The past and the present are within the field of my inquiry, but what a man may do in the future is a hard question to answer.
Translated_sentences: Mrs. Stapleton testifies that her husband had several projects in this regard: either to admonish himself to the success of South America and to prove his identity and obtain a fortune without coming to England; or to provide any partner with the required legitimacy and through his inheritance receive; or conduct the case himself on the spot, but in another external form, in such disguise, so that no one can know him.

Sentences_from: Po chwili milczenia, odebrał mi laskę i przypatrywał jej się gołem okiem.

Translated_sentences: After a while of silence, he took away my cane and stared with her bare eye.

Sentences_from: Nabieram przebiegłości: gdy doktor Mortimer nacierał, chcąc dowiedzieć się, dlaczego interesuję się panią Lyons, napytałem go podstępnie, do jakiego typu należy czaszka pana Frankland; dzięki temu, do końca naszej wycieczki nie słyszałem o niczem innem, tylko o kraniologii.
Sentences_to: I am certainly developing the wisdom of the serpent, for when Mortimer pressed his questions to an inconvenient extent I asked him casually to what type Frankland's skull belonged, and so heard nothing but craniology for the rest of our drive.

Sentences_from: Zresztą za kilka dni opuści te strony.

Sentences_from: -- Jakże się cieszę, że to ty! -- zawołałem, ściskając mu rękę.

Sentences_from: Nazajutrz, przed śniadaniem, poszedłem do pustego pokoju, nawiedzonego przez Barrymora nocy ubiegłej.

Sentences_from: Nie zwykł wyjawiać swoich planów nikomu, aż do ostatniej chwili.
Sentences_to: Partly it came no doubt from his own masterful nature, which loved to dominate and surprise those who were around him. Partly also from his professional caution, which urged him never to take any chances.
Translated_sentences: He didn't used to reveal his plans to anyone until the last minute.

Sentences_from: Zostałem odrazu wprowadzony przez schludną pokojówkę do bawialni. Pani Lyons siedziała przy maszynie Remingtona; zerwała się na moje powitanie, lecz ujrzawszy nieznajomego, zmieszała się i spytała, czego sobie życzę.
Sentences_to: A maid showed me in without ceremony, and as I entered the sitting-room a lady, who was sitting before a Remington typewriter, sprang up with a pleasant smile of welcome. Her face fell, however, when she saw that I was a stranger, and she sat down again and asked me the object of my visit.
Translated_sentences: I was repulsed by a neat maid into a playroom. Mrs. Lyons sat at Remington's machine; she broke off to my welcome, but, having seen a stranger, mixed and asked me what I wish.

Sentences_from: Jeszcze jeden dzień, dwa najwyżej, a będę w stanie zmierzyć się z tym łotrem, ale tymczasem strzeż sir Henryka; żałuję nawet, żeś go dziś opuścił.
Sentences_to: Another day--two at the most--and I have my case complete, but until then guard your charge as closely as ever a fond mother watched her ailing child. Your mission to-day has justified itself, and yet I could almost wish that you had not left his side.
Translated_sentences: One more day, two at most, and I will be able to confront this rogue, but, meanwhile, guard Sir Henry; I regret even if you left him today.

Sentences_from: -- Nie mógłbym jej oznaczyć dokładnie, ale moje wskazówki oddałyby usługę policyi.

Sentences_from: Mówiłem ci już, że twoje raporty dochodziły mnie szybko, odsyłano mi je natychmiast z Baker-Street do Coombe-Tracey.
Sentences_to: "I have already told you that your reports reached me rapidly, being forwarded instantly from Baker Street to Coombe Tracey.
Translated_sentences: I already told you that your reports were coming to me quickly, I was sent back immediately from Baker-Street to Coombe-Tracey.

Sentences_from: Powitał Holmesa z takiem uszanowaniem, jak oficer głównodowodzącego armią.
Sentences_to: I could well remember the scorn which the theories of the reasoner used then to excite in the practical man.

Sentences_from: Wszak byłeś w tym domu, Watson?
Sentences_to: You have been inside the house, have you not, Watson?

Sentences_from: Mówiłem o tem sir Henrykowi, a on, ze zwykłą sobie szczerością, wezwał Barrymora i zapytał go, czy dostał telegram.
Sentences_to: I told Sir Henry how the matter stood, and he at once, in his downright fashion, had Barrymore up and asked him whether he had received the telegram himself.
Translated_sentences: I was talking about this Sir Henry, and he, with his usual sincerity, summoned Barrymor and asked him if he had gotten a telegram.

Sentences_from: -- O jakich faktach chcesz wiedzieć? -- spytałem.
Sentences_to: "What sort of facts?" I asked.
Translated_sentences: What facts do you want to know about? - I asked.

Sentences_from: Wysunęła ręce z rękawów -- były okryte sińcami. -- Ale to najmniejsza -- ciągnęła dalej. -- On zdeptał moją duszę, poniżył ją... Wszystko znosiłam: osamotnienie, poniewierkę, dopóki mogłam wierzyć w jego miłość; ale i tu spotkał mnie zawód... Wybuchła płaczem.
Sentences_to: "Thank God! Thank God! Oh, this villain! See how he has treated me!" She shot her arms out from her sleeves, and we saw with horror that they were all mottled with bruises. "But this is nothing--nothing! It is my mind and soul that he has tortured and defiled. I could endure it all, ill-usage, solitude, a life of deception, everything, as long as I could still cling to the hope that I had his love, but now I know that in this also I have been his dupe and his tool." She broke into passionate sobbing as she spoke.
Translated_sentences: She pulled her hands out of her sleeves — they were covered with brutes. — But that's the smallest — she dragged on. — He trampled my soul, humiliated her... I endured everything: loneliness, becauseway, as long as I could believe in his love; but here the profession met me... She burst out crying.

Sentences_from: Młody Baskerville przyglądał się krajobrazowi z widoczną przyjemnością, zwłaszcza, gdyśmy wjechali w jego rodzinne Devonshire.
Sentences_to: In a very few hours the brown earth had become ruddy, the brick had changed to granite, and red cows grazed in well-hedged fields where the lush grasses and more luxuriant vegetation spoke of a richer, if a damper, climate. Young Baskerville stared eagerly out of the window, and cried aloud with delight as he recognized the familiar features of the Devon scenery.
Translated_sentences: The young Baskerville looked at the landscape with conspicuous pleasure, especially if we drove into his native Devonshire.

Sentences_from: Tymczasem sir Henryk i jego towarzyszka stanęli na ścieżce.
Sentences_to: Our friend, Sir Henry, and the lady had halted on the path and were standing deeply absorbed in their conversation, when I was suddenly aware that I was not the only witness of their interview. A wisp of green floating in the air caught my eye, and another glance showed me that it was carried on a stick by a man who was moving among the broken ground.
Translated_sentences: Meanwhile, Sir Henry and his companion stood in the path.

Sentences_from: -- Sir Karol otrzymał list tego dnia rano.
Sentences_to: "Well, Sir Henry, your uncle had a letter that morning.
